summary: This is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff discussing a potential press conference organized by Safe Horizon to publicize New York's Child Victims Act. The discussion centers on whether U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman should participate, particularly regarding the potential involvement of Jeffrey Epstein's victims and any political or investigative sensitivities.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: The primary subject of the email; his potential participation in a press conference for the Child Victims Act is being discussed. Colleagues defer to his judgment on whether the event could impact the ongoing Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Michael Polenberg
persons.context: The Safe Horizon contact hoping to organize the press conference. He is considering inviting victims of Jeffrey Epstein to participate and seeks guidance from the U.S. Attorney's Office.

connections.description: Polenberg is seeking Berman's participation and guidance for a public event related to child abuse victims, indicating a professional coordination or consultation relationship.

events.title: Proposed Child Victims Act Press Conference
events.description: A press conference planned by Safe Horizon in Times Square to mark the one-year anniversary of the New York Child Victims Act and to inform survivors about the filing window for civil suits.

events.title: Enactment of New York Child Victims Act
events.description: The New York State Child Victims Act was signed into law, creating a one-year window for adult survivors of child sexual abuse to file civil suits regardless of statutes of limitations.

events.title: Child Victims Act Filing Window Opens
events.description: The one-year window for filing civil suits under the New York Child Victims Act began.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was actively considering the public relations and investigative implications of having its top prosecutor participate in an event where Jeffrey Epstein's victims might speak.
Organizers of the Child Victims Act event explicitly considered inviting victims of Jeffrey Epstein and sought the U.S. Attorney's Office's input on that decision.
U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman expressed that he did not want to be seen as influencing the event's invite list or discouraging Epstein victims from participating.

The correspondence reveals an awareness within the U.S. Attorney's Office of an 'ongoing Epstein-related investigation' and a desire to avoid publicity that could negatively impact bringing additional charges.
The event was framed as an opportunity to publicize federal efforts to prosecute child predators and encourage victims to come forward about 'Epstein and co-conspirators'.
